verses.text: Now, we who are strong ought to bear with the weaknesses of those who are not strong, and not to please ourselves.
verses.comment: Paul urges mature believers to support those weaker in faith. The call to selflessness ties to the theme of unity found throughout the New Testament.

verses.text: Let each of us please his neighbor for his good, to build him up.
verses.comment: Building up others recalls the New Covenant command to love (John 13:34), reflecting Christ's servant leadership.

verses.text: For even Christ did not please himself, but as it is written: 'The insults of those who insulted you fell on me.'
verses.comment: Paul cites Psalm 69:9. Christ's endurance of suffering for others is the ultimate example of self-giving love, a model for all Christians.

verses.text: For everything that was written in the past was written for our instruction, so that through endurance and the encouragement of the Scriptures we might have hope.
verses.comment: Paul affirms the lasting authority and spiritual value of the Old Testament for all Christians.

verses.text: Now may the God of endurance and encouragement grant you to live in harmony with one another, according to Christ Jesus,
verses.comment: Paul prays for supernatural unity among believers, a reflection of Christ's desire for a united Church.

verses.text: so that together with one mind and one voice you may glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: The call to ‘one mind and one voice’ hints at a visible unity in worship and belief, reflecting Christ’s own prayer for oneness (John 17:21).

verses.text: Therefore, welcome one another as Christ has welcomed you, for the glory of God.
verses.comment: The act of welcoming is both a sign of grace received and a mandate to extend it broadly within the community.

verses.text: For I say that Christ became a servant to the circumcised, to show God’s truthfulness, in order to confirm the promises made to the fathers,
verses.comment: Jesus’ ministry fulfills the promises to Israel. The linkage to the patriarchs underscores continuity between Israel and the people of God.

verses.text: and for the Gentiles to glorify God for his mercy, as it is written: 'Therefore I will praise you among the nations and sing to your name.'
verses.comment: Paul references Old Testament prophecy, showing God's plan always included the Gentiles (see Gen. 12:3).

verses.text: And again it is said, 'Rejoice, O Gentiles, with his people.'
verses.comment: A direct call from Moses for Gentiles to rejoice foreshadows the universality of the Church.

verses.text: And again, 'Praise the Lord, all you Gentiles, and let all the peoples extol him.'
verses.comment: Paul’s collection of Old Testament quotations stresses God’s intention to bring all nations into praise and worship through Christ.

verses.text: And again Isaiah says, 'The root of Jesse will come, even he who arises to rule the Gentiles; in him the Gentiles will hope.'
verses.comment: A messianic prophecy. Jesus, as the root of Jesse, rules the nations. This affirms the continuity of God’s plan through the Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: May the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace as you trust in him, so that you may overflow with hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: Paul prays for joy, peace, and hope that come through the Holy Spirit—emphasizing the Spirit’s continuing work in believers’ lives.

verses.text: I myself am convinced about you, my brothers, that you are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, and able to instruct one another.
verses.comment: Paul affirms their maturity, recognizing the freedom and ability of the Church to teach and encourage each other.

verses.text: But I have written to you rather boldly on some points to remind you again, because of the grace given me by God
verses.comment: Paul’s boldness comes from his apostolic authority, a reminder of the role of divinely-appointed leaders in guiding the Church.

verses.text: to be a minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles, ministering the gospel of God, so that the offering of the Gentiles may be acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: Paul uses priestly language ('offering,' 'sanctified'), foreshadowing the importance of spiritual sacrifice and the role of leadership in the Church’s worship.

verses.text: Therefore I have reason to boast in Christ Jesus regarding the things concerning God.
verses.comment: All glory is directed to Christ, not to Paul himself.

verses.text: For I will not dare to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me for the obedience of the Gentiles by word and deed,
verses.comment: Paul’s success is attributed solely to Christ’s work through him, highlighting true humility and apostolic mission.

verses.text: by the power of signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God—so that from Jerusalem and all the way around to Illyricum, I have fulfilled the ministry of the gospel of Christ.
verses.comment: Signs and wonders accompany the apostolic ministry, authenticating it (see Acts 2:43).

verses.text: And so I made it my aim to preach the gospel where Christ has not been named, so that I would not build on another man's foundation,
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes missionary zeal and the importance of spreading the gospel everywhere.

verses.text: but as it is written: 'Those who have never been told of him will see, and those who have never heard will understand.'
verses.comment: Isaiah’s prophecy finds fulfillment in worldwide gospel proclamation.

verses.text: This is why I have often been hindered from coming to you.
verses.comment: Paul’s primary task was as a frontier missionary, which delayed his visit to Roman believers.

verses.text: But now, since I no longer have a place to work in these regions, and since I have been longing for many years to come to you,
verses.comment: Paul’s missionary work in the East neared completion, enabling him to visit Rome.

verses.text: I hope to see you in passing as I go to Spain, and to be helped on my journey there by you, once I have enjoyed your company for a while.
verses.comment: Paul seeks partnership and fellowship with the Roman church as he pushes the gospel westward.

verses.text: But now I am going to Jerusalem, bringing aid for the saints.
verses.comment: Paul’s concern for Jerusalem’s saints demonstrates charity and practical unity among believers far and wide.

verses.text: For Macedonia and Achaia have been pleased to make some contribution for the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Contributions express real solidarity and mutual dependence in the body of Christ.

verses.text: They were pleased to do it, and indeed they owe it to them; for if the Gentiles have come to share in their spiritual blessings, they ought also to serve them in material things.
verses.comment: Sharing material goods follows sharing spiritual ones. The universal Church is bound by reciprocal service.

verses.text: So, when I have completed this and have delivered their gift safely to them, I will leave for Spain by way of you.
verses.comment: Paul shows apostolic responsibility in ensuring offerings are properly delivered and accounted for.

verses.text: I know that when I come to you, I will come in the fullness of the blessing of Christ.
verses.comment: Paul’s confidence in the fullness of Christ’s blessing through sharing and fellowship hints at spiritual abundance through ecclesial unity.

verses.text: Now I urge you, brothers, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to strive together with me in prayers to God for me,
verses.comment: Paul asks for prayer, affirming the mysterious connection among all believers through the Spirit in united intercession.

verses.text: that I may be delivered from the unbelievers in Judea, and that my ministry for Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,
verses.comment: Paul’s safety and acceptance depend on God and the prayers of believers, showing the impact of the Church’s united prayer.

verses.text: so that by God’s will I may come to you with joy and be refreshed together with you.
verses.comment: Paul’s desire is for mutual encouragement—joy and refreshment through fellowship.

verses.text: May the God of peace be with you all. Amen.
verses.comment: Paul closes with a prayer for peace, a theme integral to the gospel. The peace of Christ marks the true unity of believers.
